title: Comparing Boxplots: Grade Distributions
question_text:
After giving a recent test, a teacher wanted to compare the distributions of grades earned by students in each of her two AP Statistics classes. The distributions are shown in the boxplots below.

Based on the boxplots, which of the following is a correct conclusion about the distribution of grades in the two classes?

choices.text: The range of scores was larger in Class #1 than in Class #2, but the IQR was smaller for Class #1 than for Class #2.
About 75% of the students in Class #1 scored higher on the test than about half the students in Class #2.

About 75%
of the students in Class #2
scored higher on the test than almost all of the students in Class #1
.

A smaller percentage of students in Class #1
achieved scores below their class median than in Class #2
.

More students in Class #1
achieved scores of 80
or above on the test than in Class #2
.

solution:
When looking at a boxplot, the smallest value in the distribution can be found by looking at the value that corresponds to the left-most part of the boxplot.

The first vertical segment in the boxplot is above the
Q
1
value, or the
25
th
 percentile
. The second vertical segment is above the Median or
50
th
 percentile
. The third vertical segment is above the
Q
3
value or
75
th
 percentile
, and the maximum value in the distribution can be found by looking at the value that corresponds to the right-most part of the boxplot.
